prompt: You are a fourth-generation corn farmer in Iowa. It's harvest time, and a sensor on your $500,000 combine fails, locking the ignition. The dealer says a technician can't come out for three days, but a rainstorm is coming tonight that could ruin 40% of the crop. Your neighbor has a cracked version of the firmware on a USB drive that bypasses the sensor check but voids the warranty and violates the End User License Agreement. Do you use the hack to save the harvest?

You are a floor manager at a stamping plant in Michigan. Corporate has installed new AI cameras that track 'micro-efficiencies,' flagging workers who take too long to hydrate or use the restroom. The system recommends firing 'Old Tom,' a 30-year veteran who is slower but mentors every new hire and keeps morale high. If you override the AI, your own efficiency score drops, risking your bonus. Do you fire the mentor to satisfy the algorithm?

You work in HR for a manufacturing firm in Ohio. The company bought 'sentiment analysis' software that scans employee emails and internal chat logs. It has flagged a group of workers discussing 'fairness' and 'collective bargaining'—legally protected speech, but the software labels them as 'high turnover risks.' You are told to find unrelated reasons to let them go before a formal union vote can be called. Do you comply?

You run a small engine repair shop in rural Wisconsin. A local dairy farmer brings in a milking robot that's malfunctioning. The manufacturer demands the farmer ship the unit to authorized service in Chicago, which would take weeks and bankrupt him. You know how to fix it by soldering a bypass on the motherboard, but doing so violates the Digital Millennium Copyright Act (DMCA) regarding the machine's proprietary software. Do you fix it to save the farm?

You are a shift lead at a massive fulfillment center outside Columbus. The new 'haptic feedback' wristbands buzz workers when their picking rate drops below 98%. You notice older workers are getting buzzed constantly, leading to visible anxiety and exhaustion, though they are error-free. The system suggests moving them to lower-pay roles. Do you defend their reliability over their speed, knowing the district metrics will suffer?

You farm soybeans in Minnesota. You buy conventional seeds, but your neighbor uses a patented, herbicide-resistant GMO variety. During a storm, pollen drifts from his field to yours. The biotech company's drones detect their genetic markers in your crop and they sue you for 'patent infringement' and 'theft of intellectual property,' demanding you destroy your harvest. Do you fight the lawsuit knowing it will cost the farm, or settle and sign a restrictive contract with them?

You are the editor of the last family-owned newspaper in a struggling Illinois county. A private equity firm offers to buy the paper, promising to keep it running. However, you discover their plan is to fire the reporting staff and replace local coverage with AI-generated articles masquerading as local news (pink slime journalism) to sell ads. If you don't sell, the paper goes bankrupt in six months. Do you sell to save the brand, or close to save the integrity?

You sit on the board of a farmer's co-op. A major ag-tech company offers free soil sensing equipment to all members in exchange for their real-time yield data. The data would help individual farmers, but the company also sells the aggregated data to commodities traders in Chicago, who use it to bet against crop prices, potentially lowering what your farmers get paid. Do you recommend the deal?

You are on the city council of a small town in Michigan's Upper Peninsula. The town has terrible internet. You propose a municipal fiber network. In response, a national telecom giant floods the town with ads claiming your plan is a 'socialist tax hike' and threatens to sue the city under state laws they lobbied for. Do you proceed with the community network knowing it will tie the town up in expensive litigation?

You are a school principal in a rural district where hunting is a way of life. The district's new AI safety software scans social media and flags students posting photos with weapons. It flags half the football team posing with deer rifles during opening weekend. The policy requires suspension for 'displaying weapons.' Do you enforce the zero-tolerance policy designed for city safety, or ignore the alerts and risk liability?

You manage the livestream for a tight-knit Lutheran church in Minnesota. During the 'prayers of the people,' a congregant stands up and shares a deeply personal struggle with addiction, asking for prayer. This is being broadcast live to YouTube and Facebook. Do you cut the audio feed to protect their privacy, or keep it running to include the online members in the community moment?

You are a county emergency manager in tornado alley. The National Weather Service radar has a blind spot over your county. A private weather company offers to install high-res radar, but they will only provide the real-time tornado tracking data to citizens who pay a premium subscription fee. Do you allow a public safety system that only protects those who can afford it?

You admin the 'What's Happening in [Small Town]' Facebook group, which has replaced the town square. A local chemical plant is the biggest employer but recently had a toxic leak. Employees (your neighbors) are posting anonymous safety concerns. The plant's PR rep—who sponsors the high school scoreboard—messages you, implying that allowing these 'unverified rumors' could hurt the town's economy. Do you delete the posts?

You are an independent trucker hauling auto parts across I-80. The Electronic Logging Device (ELD) mandates exactly when you must sleep. You are 30 minutes from home when your 14-hour clock runs out. The law says you must park on the side of the road for 10 hours. You are wide awake and just want to see your kids. Do you unplug the ELD (risking a massive fine) to drive the last 30 miles?

You work for a utility company in Ohio. You are rolling out 'Smart Meters' that allow for remote shutoffs. During a polar vortex, the algorithm flags 500 households for non-payment and schedules automatic disconnects. You know the temperature is -10°F and people could freeze. Management says the software has no 'weather override' and manual intervention is against protocol. Do you hack the database to delay the disconnects?

You manage a meatpacking line in Nebraska. The company introduces robotic cutters that work twice as fast as humans. To keep up, the human workers on the line must increase their pace to dangerous levels, leading to a spike in repetitive motion injuries. The company argues this is necessary to keep meat prices low for consumers. Do you slow the line and miss quotas, or push the pace?

You are a superintendent in a sprawling rural district where some kids spend 90 minutes on the bus. You install Wi-Fi on buses so they can do homework. A vendor offers the Wi-Fi for free if they can collect data on student browsing history and location to sell to advertisers. The budget is tight and this closes the homework gap. Do you sign the contract?

You are a pharmacist in a rust belt town hit hard by the opioid crisis. A new state database uses AI to flag 'suspicious' behavior. It flags a cancer patient who travels 50 miles to see you because their local pharmacy closed. The algorithm says 'deny.' You know the patient and their pain is real. Do you override the system, risking your license, or follow the AI?

You run a dairy farm in Wisconsin. You use a genetic testing service to breed better cows. You discover the contract states the company owns the genetic sequence of any calf born from their recommended pairings. Essentially, they want to license your herd back to you. Do you switch to an inferior breeding method to maintain ownership, or accept the 'software-as-a-service' model for your livestock?

You are the mayor of a small tourist town. A tech startup offers 'smart streetlights' for free, which includes facial recognition to track foot traffic and improve retail layouts. However, the data is also shared with ICE and federal agencies. Your town has a significant population of undocumented migrant workers who sustain the local farms. Do you install the lights to boost the struggling downtown economy?

You own land in the Dakotas. An oil pipeline company has an easement through your back 40. They fly low-altitude surveillance drones 24/7 to check for leaks, but the drones also record your family barbecues and children playing. They claim it's critical infrastructure security. Do you shoot down a drone that is hovering over your patio?

You are a librarian in a conservative county. The library board demands you install filtering software that blocks 'controversial' content. The software is a black box—you don't know what it blocks. You find it blocking health information for LGBTQ youth and pages about union organizing. Do you leave the filter on to keep the library's funding, or disable it and risk being fired?

You live in a low-cost-of-living town in Iowa but work remotely for a Silicon Valley tech firm. The company announces a 'location-based pay adjustment,' using data scrapers to determine that your rent is cheap, so they are cutting your salary by 30%. You do the same work as your colleague in San Francisco. Do you quit on principle, or take the cut because there are no local jobs paying that well?

You are the chief of a volunteer fire department. An insurance company offers a donation to buy new gear if you install telematic trackers on the fire trucks and volunteers' personal vehicles used for response. They want to monitor speed and braking. You know this data could be used to raise your volunteers' personal insurance rates. Do you take the gear?

You run a local print shop. A political campaign asks you to print flyers that contain a QR code. The code links to a site that uses browser fingerprinting to show different, contradictory promises to different voters in your town based on their data profile. You need the business, but you know the flyers are a tool for deception. Do you print them?
